# Land Carbon Dynamics

Forests absorb carbon from the atmosphere, helping offset human-produced carbon emissions. But measurements from space show the ability of forests across the world to absorb carbon is declining.

# Land Carbon Dynamics

Forests absorb carbon from the atmosphere, helping offset human-produced carbon emissions. But measurements from space show the ability of forests across the world to absorb carbon is declining.

slides.text:
##  Measuring Biomass from Space

Carbon is continually exchanged between the atmosphere and land surface. Carbon sinks remove carbon from the atmosphere, helping to offset natural and human carbon emissions. Whether an area is a carbon source or a sink can flip through the year, and in response to environmental changes such as droughts, wildfires and land use.

ESA’s Regional Carbon Cycle Analysis and Processes project (RECCAP2) uses satellites to measure land climate variables such as soil moisture and biomass. The L-band microwave radiometer on the SMOS satellite is sensitive to annual changes in vegetation, including forests.

These observations are combined with ground data and computer models to map global land carbon stocks. Earth’s forests store carbon as woody biomass, but environmental changes can impair their ability to absorb carbon.

slides.text:
## Amazon Basin

The Amazon Basin accounts for 14% of the atmospheric carbon taken up by plants each year. But the region has lost 370 million tonnes of carbon over the decade 2010-20, and the southeastern part is now a net carbon source. Carbon absorption by growing forest has been outweighed by deforestation, degradation and agricultural use.

##  Northern Forests

41% of the world’s forest area is in the northern hemisphere. Northern forests have been accumulating biomass in recent decades. But since 2016 increasing droughts and wildfires have weakened their capacity to absorb carbon.

slides.text:
##  European Emissions Offset

Across Europe, forests absorbed about 10% of the EU’s greenhouse gas emissions between 1990 and 2022. But in the last ten years this emissions offset has declined by nearly 30% due to forest harvesting and ageing, more frequent droughts, heatwaves and wildfires, plus insect outbreaks and plant disease. This decline poses a risk to achieving future European climate goals.

Improved knowledge of land carbon dynamics will help us gauge how much carbon budget is left within the Paris Agreement temperature limits, or if we’ll have to deal with the more severe consequences of further warming.
